reviewText: Moonbase Alpha is a marvel of the 21st century. You cannot even compare any other games like Gears of War, Call of Duty, Team Fortress 2, or even Assassin's Creed to this landmark in human intelligence. If you were to put a average Joe into this kind of enviroment, his head would implode from the amazing graphics, story, and gameplay. If you were to play this game, your feeble monkey brain would not even be able to understand the deep, complex and twisted story of Moonbase Alpha. NASA's masterpiece of 2010 shows us how far America has come in understanding space and lifestyle in space. Moonbase Alpha shows that even through NASA, we can learn much more about space and the human psyche. Moonbase Alpha follows the story of astronaut John Madden and his daily life on Moonbase Alpha, NASAs experimental base on the moon. If John fails his secret mission objective, his family and status in the NFL will be taken away and soiled by NASA. Moonbase Alpha brings us this harrowing story along with intense gameplay elements such as fixing carbon dioxide leaks, repairing solar panels, and driving robots. If you even attempted to finish such a hard, cruel game, you would be hailed as a god among men. Jesus would bless you with immortality and wealth beyond comprehension. The graphics in Moonbase Alpha top even Crysis 3 and have made many a computer catch fire. Even my IBM Super Computer cannot handle such a masterpiece as Moonbase Alpha. Many will look back to this game in the future, and smile as they remember their glorious past. NASA will forever be hailed as the wunderkind of this millenia. Thank you, NASA, for creating such a wonderful and exciting game.

reviewText: Set in Iraq, Moonbase Alpha is a hyper-realistic war simulation, rivaling ARMA in terms of AI, graphics, and controls. The game's main feature is its well-tuned multiplayer, which I noticed no lag while playing. Moonbase Alpha's amount of customization is simply astounding -- you can entirely adjust your character's appearance, which ranges from the clothes they wear depending on the weather, their face, the tint of their skin, how shiny their skin is, their skin color, how rough their skin is, how dirty their skin is, so forth. The character generation can take years to finish due to how complex it is. Alongside its extensive multiplayer, Moonbase Alpha also boasts a story that's Shakespearan in breadth, questioning the very morality of war and the existence of humanity. All of this is topped with an extensive soundtrack done from the incredible Jesper Kyd, who gives his best performance here. His soundtrack is diverse -- ranging from opera, electro, heavy metal, and dubstep. Going over everything that makes this game simply the greatest game ever made would render this review too long for Steam to post, so I'll end the review by saying that Moonbase Alpha will change your life.

reviewText:
Moonbase Alpha... Houston, we have a great game

NASA really did good with this one, ESPECIALLY since it’s free.
Your job is simple, fix Moonbase Alpha's life support systems using various tools and drones.

I have always wanted a great space simulator, and stupidly I left this gem untouched in my games library for over a month believing because it was free, Moonbase would be garbage. I was wrong. Very wrong.
So to start off with, you choose how you want your game to be set up from the menu, this includes map size, if there’s a time limit or not, the name and password of the server, and even if you want it to be single player if you desire. From there you’re shown a brief cutscene, followed by a simple 'tutorial' telling how to get things done.
The goal of the game is to repair the base as fast as you can. This is done by repairing solar panels, replacing broken couplers, and attaching disconnected tubes.

From pulling down solar panels, to using a computer operated drone to repair oxygen filters in hazardous areas, this game is very pleasing, especially the slow, awkward movements. Taking forever to walk thirty feet is defiantly more pleasing than it would seem, and you genuinely feel as if you’re on the moon. Making it better is that almost everything is silent, with the exception of your footsteps and the beautiful soundtrack.
You can even team up with some buddies online to try to beat your previous time records, and the Text-to-Speech option can create some hilarious conversations.

Now, if there were more levels you could choose from, and some minor bugs worked out, this game would be a true masterpiece.

Pros:
entirely free
shows off some pretty cool NASA tech
you’re on the moon
soundtrack is amazing
movement feels as it should for being on the moon
online servers or single player
Text-to-Speech

Cons:
only 1 map (with multiple sizes)
occasional bugs
if online you're most likely going to hear some naughty things

Rate: 8/10

If you love space in anyway at all, get this game. Heck, even if you don’t like space get this game!

Well, if you want to know what it might be like to be on the Moon then try out this game, but you should not expect much.

NASA should have taken more content from the 1974 tv series Moonbase alpha (MA).
The game was released on July 6, 2010, as a free download on Steam. (http://store.steampowered.com/app/39000/)

But that is a different mia issue.)

With a mixed reception, MA is an exercise in text to speech functionality and repetitive gameplay where one to six people try to shorten the time it takes to accomplish the repair O2 mission. One person can do it in 30 - 40 min, the curent record time is like 6 min (likely he had five other people helping get that time.)
No obvious way to submit bug reports in this four year old game: hacking of audio files to intentionally irritate fellows on the map, intentionally obstructing completing the mission with no way to kick the person besides a password protected instance, and mouse click that subdues the game to task bar...

Not sure what NASA/Army Game Studio has been doing on this for the last four years (the Unreal 3 engine MA uses came out in 2004. UE4 came out 2012) but they have not really put effort into updating this MA exercise.
As a free game and only 1.1GB install, it is a fun passtime, you can even compete against another team for fastest completion time... sabotuers not withstanding!

reviewText:
Moonbase Alpha is a wonderful experience. You can tell the creators of this game were all very experienced at creating games. This piece is beautiful. The game boasts an amazing landscape varying from white moon dust, to rocks, to the black abyss that is space, and even the earth from afar. The shadows are also very notable as they all move very fluently. Along with the environment, the game has a wonderful soundtrack. Three songs on loop that really bring out the emotion of every moment. Weather you be waddling around on the moon, dragging pipes around, driving a robot like it is a NASCAR race, or just spewing crap out of your mouth there is a song for it. The story is also wonderful. Plot twists kept me on my feet and the incentive kept me playing for a whole 3 hours. The voice actors are also all-star. The game has my favorite voice actor of all time in it... A speak and spell. The game has too many features to list there so I will choose some of my favorites. Markers can be placed and can say things such as Communist" or "John Madden". You can pick things up... Only to drop them when you realize there is nothing you can do with the item you are holding. You can also communicate with other players through text like "aeiou" or "John Madden John Madden John Madden John Madden John Madden John Madden". No matter what it is the game has something for you.

10/10 would wank to this again.

reviewText: This miracle of german engineering stands out from most action rpgs because of the way it seemlessly integrates first person shooter elements. This game takes place in post-apocolyptic russia in which an ex KGB officer named John Madden must deal with the death of his family, as well as many other personal problems. Infinity Ward really hit it out of the park with this latest game and it shows as this game has recieved critical acclaim such as winning GOTY for 4 straight years in a row 2 Oscars, and 7 Emmys. One reason why this game has earned such praise is the variety of servers, weapons, game modes, weekly updates, and the immersive story. And a huge plus is that when you download this game you recieve a free copy of the beta of the upcoming, highly anticipated, Madden NFL '95.\n\n10/10

reviewText: This game is amazingly well constructed. It gives the player a realistic feeling of practicing the skills necessary to join the space program at NASA. This game has many features that allow you to hone your skills before you even graduate High School - imagine how well your application to any college will look like with first hand experience in equipment management in zero gravity conditions. This game allows you to ramp the barren landscape on the moon in rovers that were designed to slowly travel across the ground and you can take advantage of them to fly off rock piles going at least 10 miles an hour. While this game is a serious perspective on the moon, it also features a dark side. Unknown aliens trying to communicate to you, kids somehow landing and trying to communicate, I believe I even bumped into someone who was singing but burst into a fit of coughs before he could finish. If I could go higher, I would, but I'll settle and give this game a solid 10 out of 10. Definitely life changing yet eye opening at the same time. With a game like this, you have to ask yourself. Do YOU have what it takes to be a whaler on the moon?

reviewText:
Moonbase Alpha  - NASA's exceptional lunar simulator. This game lets you be a real astronaut on the surface of the moon! You even get to simulate the exciting day of an astronaut on the moon with others with the amazing multiplayer mode!

This game lets you do anything you desire; from remote-controlling robots with tools to remote-controlling rovers; it all works out, just by sticking your backpack into the modules! You also get to repair awesome moon things and you can even build your own moon base! Sort of. This game is highly competitive with the new competitive gamemode they have introduced. Never before have I felt like a real astronaut before!

On the technical side of things, the game boasts with an amazing graphics engine that 2005 PCs could barely ever run. The sounds are highly realistic, as there are no sounds in space! However, in the multiplayer, you get to turn on the amazing text-to-speech feature, that pronounces everything you say and makes communication and survival on your very own moonbase much easier! Recommmended for people that do not know what a videogame is.

reviewText: More than an average simulator, this is a cosmic epic. Moonbase Alpha is by far one of the most immersive game experiences I've had in a long time. The game takes place on a small astronaut colony that has been disrupted by an asteroid. As one of six colored space colonists, you race against time to repair the oxygen tanks for your living quarters, or die trying. The important aspect of Moonbase Alpha is that it is not your typical simulator. It is meant for education. Players work together trying to teach each other not only how to play the game, but how to pronounce vowels, informing others about the life of former professional football player John Madden, and how to sing.\n\nMoonbase Alpha is one of the most important games of this generation. I rate it a cool out of yes.

reviewText:
There may have been updates since I last played this, however the version I installed was an interesting little simulator. There was some educational value to be had, but not much. The game play is also not very intuitive and could benefit from tutorials. The game seemed to be very stable, however it had issues in multiplayer missions due to children constantly attempting to grief players by undermining the work of those attempting to accomplish the mission within the allotted time limit.
If there was more content, specifically missions, or perhaps there was a sandbox mode available during Alpha in which players could use to simply build with, this would have real value. As it is, it's simply a toy for wasting time.

I am recommending this for younger children or anyone who has an interest in real life space exploration, as these are the individuals most likely to enjoy this. That said, I do not think it will be able to keep anyones attention for very long unless content is added.

There may have been updates since I last played this, however the version I installed was an interesting little simulator. There was some educational value to be had, but not much. The game play is also not very intuitive and could benefit from tutorials. The game seemed to be very stable, however it had issues in multiplayer missions due to children constantly attempting to grief players by undermining the work of those attempting to accomplish the mission within the allotted time limit.
If there was more content, specifically missions, or perhaps there was a sandbox mode available during Alpha in which players could use to simply build with, this would have real value. As it is, it's simply a toy for wasting time.

I am recommending this for younger children or anyone who has an interest in real life space exploration, as these are the individuals most likely to enjoy this. That said, I do not think it will be able to keep anyones attention for very long unless content is added.

There's a lot of commands online that are fun to play with, though I advise you don't do it excessively.

Overall, it's simple, it's playable, it has it's own charm, I say definitely get it if you're looking for a time waster.
